codes.verbatim_quote: Okay, so I'm on the first phase, I'm trying to get a grasp of how the interface works. Okay, go to the catalogue. Okay, automatically logged in. Okay, so here I can see journal articles, journal issues, volumes, and manifestation, which should be okay
codes.context: User successfully navigated to the catalogue and immediately understood the available resource types

codes.verbatim_quote: Only one journal, okay, you can see identifiers, titles. Okay, the other resources referencing this journal, or rather I guess other resources inside this journal. Okay. Okay, nice. Okay, nice. Okay
codes.context: User quickly grasped how resources are organized and how relationships between resources are displayed

codes.verbatim_quote: Okay, time vault, let's see. Oh, time vault only shows deleted resources. Nice
codes.context: User quickly understood the purpose and function of the time vault feature

codes.verbatim_quote: Okay, let's try setting the DOI with this value, which is ISSN value. Let's try and see if it works. Of course, it will be wrong. Okay, try updating things first. I think I am already updating things. It looks like I'm trying to set this value for a DOI instead of an ISSN. Maybe this isn't okay, let's try something else
codes.context: User discovered a validation bug: when changing identifier type from ISSN to DOI while keeping the same invalid value, the system neither showed validation errors nor detected changes when saving, indicating flawed validation logic

codes.verbatim_quote: I'll try and see if there is any other mention of fabio:JournalArticle in the SHACL Shape file
codes.context: User double-checking SHACL file structure before modifying shapes to ensure no conflicts

codes.verbatim_quote: So I'll save this and try to try the reloading. Okay, and let's see if I can, for example, modify a journal article by adding an abstract. So, okay, journal article expression, title, author... uh, let's try edit resource. I don't want to add an identifier. I would like to add... add... add abstract. Here it is, okay
codes.context: User successfully implemented SHACL validation for abstract property and immediately verified it works by finding the new field available

codes.verbatim_quote: This is kind of strange. I would like to see like just the abstract, like label, and not the whole UI
codes.context: User noticing that abstract field appears differently than expected after adding SHACL validation

codes.verbatim_quote: I'm not sure that this is already like enforced by placing abstract here right under the display rule for the title property
codes.context: User expressing doubt about whether position in display rules affects field ordering in the interface

codes.verbatim_quote: Oh nice, nice! This is okay. So it is enough to place the rule under title to see in the display rules, to see the label I want, where I want it
codes.context: User discovered that display rule positioning affects field order in UI and expressed satisfaction with the intuitive behavior

codes.verbatim_quote: Now I'll try reloading it and see how it is displayed. Okay, nice. Yeah, this is what I would expect. Let's see time machine just by curiosity. Okay, so I would expect to see the modifications I did, I just did here. Okay, okay, very nice, very nice, seems to work pretty well
codes.context: User successfully tested the implemented feature and verified change tracking works as expected through the time machine feature

codes.verbatim_quote: And let's change from simple text field to a multi-line textarea. Okay, very nice. Okay, so I'm stopping the recording right now
codes.context: User expressed satisfaction at successfully completing both SHACL validation and display rule configuration tasks

codes.verbatim_quote: Very much, the immediate graphical feedback was a great help to see if I had met the requests of the testing protocol.
codes.context: User values real-time visual confirmation that their actions meet system requirements or task objectives

codes.verbatim_quote: Being able to modify records data via a graphical interface and apply the changes in the backend in just a few clicks.
codes.context: User appreciates the streamlined workflow from UI modifications to backend application with minimal steps

codes.verbatim_quote: The provenance tracking is very useful also for restoring previous states of the data.
codes.context: User recognizes the practical utility of provenance features specifically for data recovery and version control

codes.verbatim_quote: having more comments on the default yaml file would have been helpful to understand the inner working more quickly without the need to get back to the documentation.
codes.context: User identifies need for inline documentation in configuration files to reduce dependency on external documentation
User expresses satisfaction with current feature set when asked about additional needs, indicating system adequacy

codes.verbatim_quote: It was not frustrating, but having come comments on the default yaml file would have been helpful
codes.context: User explicitly states the overall experience was not frustrating, even when suggesting improvements
